awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  L.E.A.R.N.ing to Build STEM Research Communities - A Proposal to Strengthen, Expand, and Disseminate a Successful Retention Model
awd_abstract_narration:
A previous NSF-supported project has resulted in high retention and improved GPA for STEM majors at the University of Central Florida.  In an effort to expand on this work the institution has partnered with investigators at the University of NC-Wilmington (a primarily undergraduate, public institution) and Florida Atlantic University (a research-1, public institution) to study the ways in which a community built on disciplinary research will affect the retention of first-year students in STEM.  The participants will live together in a learning community, take courses together, and work as research apprentices in faculty laboratories.  This model, which has been shown to be particularly effective with students from underrepresented groups and first generation majors, will be adapted to include strategies for retaining transfer students through to graduation as well.

The core elements of the UCF model are the development of an academic research community that provides students with hands-on learning opportunities, access to faculty and trained graduate student and peer research mentors, and integration into student life through a wide variety of academic, social, and service activities.  This project will address three research questions that are central to the national goal of increasing the number of high quality STEM graduates who go on to graduate school and into the workforce: (a) Can the UCF research community model be adapted successfully to accommodate a transfer student population? (b) What factors within a STEM research community influence transfer student success and impact transfer student retention? And (c) To what extent is the retention success of a current model replicable at other, public institutions?  Formative and summative assessment will focus on the efficacy of the model on student retention and success in STEM for the different student populations (first-year and transfer) and at different institutions.  The plan will use a mixed-method approach to assess the effectiveness of the proposed educational tools and educational content in fulfilling the desired learning outcomes, from both educators' and participants' perspectives.  Student retention and GPA will be compared to matched cohorts.  The findings from this project will be presented at state and national meetings such as the Florida Statewide Symposium on Engagement in Undergraduate Research and the Council on Undergraduate Research biennial conference.  Results will also be submitted to the Journal of College Science Teaching.

por.por_cntn:
The Learning Environment and Academic Research Network (LEARN) model was developed at the University of Central Florida (UCF) with funding from a previous NSF grant to improve the retention and graduation rates of first-year students in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines. Our strategy in this project has students live together in a learning community, take courses together, and work as research apprentices in faculty laboratories. Results from the first LEARN cohorts show improved retention rates, graduation rates, and critical thinking skills.  To determine if the success of this program at UCF is more broadly applicable, faculty at UCF partnered with faculty at Florida Atlantic University (FAU) and Western Carolina University (WCU) in a 5-year study. Building upon the success achieved by the UCF first-time-in-college (FTIC) students (F-LEARN for first-year students), we adapted this model for use at both FAU and WCU.  In addition,  F-LEARN was modified further to accommodate incoming upper-division Associate in Arts (AA) transfer STEM students (T-LEARN for transfer students) at UCF and we extended the T-LEARN model to FAU and WCU to form the LEARN Consortium. 

The two research questions our proposal put forth included:  (1) To what extent can we positively impact transfer student STEM retention and success by adopting a successful STEM FTIC community-cohort undergraduate research model to an AA transfer student population at three institutions, and (2) To what extent can we replicate the retention success of an FTIC community-cohort undergraduate research program at two other institutions? 

To answer these questions, we implemented the following goals: (a) Adapt the current F-LEARN model to a transfer student population (T-LEARN) at UCF, FAU, and WCU, (b) Implement the LEARN model for FTIC students (F-LEARN) to WCU and FAU, (c) Assess the impacts of the LEARN consortium on student retention and success in STEM for different student populations and at different institutions, and (d) Disseminate the LEARN model to expand the LEARN consortium.  The new model was developed by adapting UCF's successful retention model for 1st-year students that centers around three main pillars: (1) academics/research, (2) mentoring, and (3) community building (Meeroff et al. 2020). 

Our overall findings from the three institutions indicate that T-LEARN students’ involvement in research during their 1st year was the most significant factor within the T-LEARN program that contributed to their academic success (Chamely et al. 2021). Additionally, the majority of these students continued to do research with the same LEARN program faculty mentor one year, and sometimes longer, after the program ended. The consortium continues to explore how F-LEARN adaptation has impacted students on the WCU and FAU campuses (Kwochka et al. In Prep). 

The F-LEARN program at WCU ended after its 4th year in the 2019/2020 academic year as the original grant proposal outlined.  We continue to monitor the long-term success of the program and this grant helped us holistically learn about the long-term impact of this program on FTIC students.  A total of 42 out of 55 FTIC students have matriculated through the WCU F-LEARN program over that four-year period. During the first two years of the LEARN program, retention and graduation rates of the LEARN students with our comparison group were similar.  However, when we became more experienced with our curriculum and how to run the LEARN program, the year-to-year retention rates were significantly better than their comparison groups, while the overall graduation rates remained comparable.  For example, in the 2019/2020 academic year, the F-LEARN cohort (80%) had a much higher first-year retention rate than did their comparison group (63%).  We also report (Schneider et al. 2021) that students are 2.5 times more likely to be involved in research post-LEARN compared to the matched comparison group. 

The T-LEARN program at WCU has shown similar encouraging results. By spring 2022, 83% of the 2018/2019 cohort had graduated in a STEM discipline, whereas only 74% of that year’s matched comparison group had graduated.  Likewise, in the spring of 2022,  50% of T-LEARN students had graduated from WCU in two years, while 0% of the students in the matched comparison group had graduated.  Finally, many of these T-LEARN students continued with undergraduate research throughout their time at WCU.

The LEARN consortium team collaborated very effectively during the entire 5-year grant period (and two no-cost extensions for both WCU and FAU) to provide students in the program with tremendous opportunities throughout their experience. To date, the team has made 17 presentations/workshops at conferences, published three manuscripts, and we have three additional papers in preparation.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2022
Modified by: William R Kwochka
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Learning Environment and Academic Research Network (LEARN) model was developed at the University of Central Florida (UCF) with funding from a previous NSF grant to improve the retention and graduation rates of first-year students in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines. In addition,  F-LEARN was modified further to accommodate incoming upper-division Associate in Arts (AA) transfer STEM students (T-LEARN for transfer students) at UCF and we extended the T-LEARN model to FAU and WCU to form the LEARN Consortium.

To answer these questions, we implemented the following goals: (a) Adapt the current F-LEARN model to a transfer student population (T-LEARN) at UCF, FAU, and WCU, (b) Implement the LEARN model for FTIC students (F-LEARN) to WCU and FAU, (c) Assess the impacts of the LEARN consortium on student retention and success in STEM for different student populations and at different institutions, and (d) Disseminate the LEARN model to expand the LEARN consortium.  The new model was developed by adapting UCF's successful retention model for 1st-year students that centers around three main pillars: (1) academics/research, (2) mentoring, and (3) community building (Meeroff et al. 2020). 
Our overall findings from the three institutions indicate that T-LEARN students’ involvement in research during their 1st year was the most significant factor within the T-LEARN program that contributed to their academic success (Chamely et al. 2021). The F-LEARN program at WCU ended after its 4th year in the 2019/2020 academic year as the original grant proposal outlined. For example, in the 2019/2020 academic year, the F-LEARN cohort (80%) had a much higher first-year retention rate than did their comparison group (63%). By spring 2022, 83% of the 2018/2019 cohort had graduated in a STEM discipline, whereas only 74% of that year’s matched comparison group had graduated.  Likewise, in the spring of 2022,  50% of T-LEARN students had graduated from WCU in two years, while 0% of the students in the matched comparison group had graduated. To date, the team has made 17 presentations/workshops at conferences, published three manuscripts, and we have three additional papers in preparation.
